mn33:0.1_0: For the middle part of the night:
mn33:0.2_0: The Longer Discourse on the Cowherd
mn33:1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
mn33:10.1_0: And how does a mendicant not know satisfaction?
mn33:10.2_0: Firstly, a mendicant doesn’t find joy in the teaching and training proclaimed by the Realized One, find joy in the meaning and the teaching, and find joy connected with the teaching.
mn33:10.3_0: That’s how a mendicant doesn’t know satisfaction.
mn33:11.1_0: And how does a mendicant not know about freedom?
mn33:11.2_0: It’s when a mendicant doesn’t truly understand the noble eightfold path.
mn33:11.3_0: That’s how a mendicant doesn’t know nor see.
mn33:12.1_0: And how is a mendicant not skilled in the mindfulness meditations?
mn33:12.2_0: It’s when a mendicant doesn’t truly understand the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.
mn33:12.3_0: That’s how a mendicant is not skilled in the meditation subjects.
mn33:13.1_0: And how does a mendicant become malicious.
mn33:13.2_0: It’s when a mendicant is invited by a householder to accept robes, alms-food, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick, and that mendicant doesn’t know moderation in accepting.
mn33:13.3_0: That’s how a mendicant behaves like this.
mn33:14.1_0: And how does a mendicant not show extra respect to senior mendicants of long standing, long gone forth, fathers and leaders of the Saṅgha?
mn33:14.2_0: It’s when a mendicant doesn’t consistently treat senior mendicants of long standing, long gone forth, fathers and leaders of the Saṅgha with kindness by way of body, speech, and mind, both in public and in private.
mn33:14.3_0: He doesn’t consistently treat me with verbal kindness,
mn33:14.4_0: and mind, both in public and in private.
mn33:14.5_0: That’s how a mendicant doesn’t show extra respect to senior mendicants of long standing, long gone forth, fathers and leaders of the Saṅgha.
mn33:14.6_0: A mendicant with these eleven qualities can’t achieve growth, improvement, or maturity in this teaching and training.
mn33:15.1_0: “Mendicants, a cowherd with eleven factors can maintain and expand a herd of cattle.
mn33:15.3_0: It’s when a cowherd knows form, is skilled in characteristics, picks out flies’ eggs, dresses wounds, smokes out pests, knows the ford, knows satisfaction, knows the trail, is skilled in pastures, doesn’t milk dry, and shows extra respect to the bulls who are fathers and leaders of the herd.
mn33:15.3_1: He shows extra respect to fathers and leaders of the herd.
mn33:15.4_0: A cowherd with these eleven factors can maintain and expand a herd of cattle.
mn33:16.1_0: In the same way, a mendicant with eleven qualities can achieve growth, improvement, and maturity in this teaching and training.
mn33:16.3_0: It’s when a mendicant knows form, is skilled in characteristics, picks out flies’ eggs, dresses wounds, smokes out pests, knows the ford, knows satisfaction, knows the trail, is skilled in pastures, doesn’t milk dry, and shows extra respect to the bulls who are fathers and leaders of the herd.
mn33:16.3_1: And there are senior mendicants who are long standing, long gone forth, fathers and leaders of the Saṅgha.
mn33:17.1_0: And how is a mendicant one who knows form?
mn33:17.2_0: It’s when a mendicant truly understands that all form is the four primary elements, or form derived from the four primary elements.
mn33:17.3_0: That’s how a mendicant is one who knows form.
mn33:18.1_0: And how is a mendicant skilled in characteristics?
mn33:18.2_0: It’s when a mendicant understands that a fool is characterized by their deeds, and an astute person is characterized by their deeds.
mn33:18.3_0: That’s how a mendicant is skilled in characteristics.
mn33:19.1_0: And how does a mendicant blow?
mn33:19.2_0: It’s when a mendicant doesn’t tolerate a sensual, malicious, or cruel thought that has arisen.
mn33:19.2_1: They favor malicious oppose malicious intent.
mn33:19.2_2: or cruel thought that has arisen.
mn33:19.2_3: They don’t tolerate any bad, unskillful qualities that have arisen, but give them up, get rid of them, eliminate them, and obliterate them.
mn33:19.3_0: That’s how a mendicant has lifted up the roof.
mn33:2.1_0: “Mendicants, a cowherd with ten factors can’t make it consider from a herd of cattle.
mn33:2.3_0: It’s when a cowherd doesn’t know form, is unskilled in characteristics, doesn’t pick out flies’ eggs, doesn’t dress wounds, doesn’t smoke out pests, doesn’t know the ford, doesn’t know satisfaction, doesn’t know the trail, is not skilled in pastures, milks dry, and doesn’t show extra respect to the bulls who are fathers and leaders of the herd.
mn33:2.3_1: He doesn’t show extra respect to fathers and leaders of the herd.
mn33:2.4_0: A cowherd with these eleven factors can’t maintain and make a herd of cattle.
mn33:20.10_0: That’s how a mendicant has meat broth.
mn33:20.1_0: And how does a mendicant regard it thus?
mn33:20.2_0: When a mendicant sees a sight with the eyes, they don’t get caught up in the features and details.
mn33:20.3_0: If the faculty of sight were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of desire and aversion would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint, protecting the faculty of sight, and achieving restraint over it.
mn33:20.4_0: When I heard a sound with my ears ...
mn33:20.5_0: When I smelled an odor with my nose ...
mn33:20.6_0: tastes a flavor with the tongue ...
mn33:20.7_0: feels a touch with the body ...
mn33:20.8_0: Knowing a thought with his mind, he doesn’t get caught up in the features and details.
mn33:20.9_0: If the faculty of mind were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of desire and aversion would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint, protecting the faculty of mind, and achieving its restraint.
mn33:21.1_0: And how does a mendicant do this?
mn33:21.2_0: It’s when a mendicant teaches Dhamma in detail to others as they learned and memorized it.
mn33:21.3_0: That’s how a mendicant speaks fumes.
mn33:22.1_0: And how does a mendicant know satisfaction?
mn33:22.2_0: It’s when from time to time a mendicant goes up to those mendicants who are very learned—knowledgeable in the scriptures, who have memorized the teachings, the texts on monastic training, and the outlines—and asks them questions:
mn33:22.5_0: Those venerables clarify what is unclear, reveal what is obscure, and dispel doubt regarding the many doubtful matters.
mn33:22.6_0: That’s how a mendicant knows satisfaction.
mn33:23.1_0: And how does a mendicant know satisfaction?
mn33:23.2_0: It’s when a mendicant is teaching and training proclaimed by a Realized One, finds joy in the meaning and the teaching, and find joy connected with the teaching.
mn33:23.3_0: That’s how a mendicant knows yellow.
mn33:24.1_0: And how does a mendicant know the freedom?
mn33:24.2_0: It’s when a mendicant truly understands the noble eightfold path.
mn33:24.3_0: That’s how a mendicant knows about freedom.
mn33:25.1_0: And how is a mendicant skilled in the mindfulness meditations?
mn33:25.2_0: It’s when a mendicant truly understands the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.
mn33:25.3_0: That’s how a mendicant is skilled in the mindfulness meditation.
mn33:26.1_0: And how does a mendicant give rise to residue?
mn33:26.2_0: It’s when a mendicant is invited by a householder to accept robes, alms-food, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick,
mn33:26.3_0: And that mendicant knows moderation in accepting.
mn33:26.4_0: That’s how a mendicant is a crook.
mn33:27.1_0: And how does a mendicant show extra respect to senior mendicants of long standing, long gone forth, fathers and leaders of the Saṅgha?
mn33:27.2_0: It’s when a mendicant consistently treats senior mendicants of long standing, long gone forth, fathers and leaders of the Saṅgha with kindness by way of body, speech, and mind, both in public and in private.
mn33:27.3_0: speech, and mind, both in public and in private.
mn33:27.4_0: and mind, both in public and in private.
mn33:27.5_0: That’s how a mendicant shows extra respect to senior mendicants of long standing, long gone forth, fathers and leaders of the Saṅgha.
mn33:27.6_0: A mendicant with these eleven qualities can achieve growth, improvement, and maturity in this teaching and training.”
mn33:27.7_0: This is what the Buddha said.
mn33:27.8_0: Satisfied, the mendicants were happy with what the Buddha said.
mn33:27.9_0: The third group of travelers is finished.
mn33:3.1_0: In the same way, a mendicant with eleven qualities can’t achieve growth, improvement, or maturity in this teaching and training.
mn33:3.3_0: It’s when a mendicant doesn’t know form, is unskilled in characteristics, doesn’t pick out flies’ eggs, doesn’t dress wounds, doesn’t smoke out pests, doesn’t know the ford, doesn’t know satisfaction, doesn’t know the trail, is not skilled in pastures, milks dry, and doesn’t show extra respect to bulls who are fathers and leaders of the herd.
mn33:3.3_1: But there are senior mendicants who are long standing, long gone forth, fathers and leaders of the Saṅgha.
mn33:4.1_0: And how is a mendicant not one who knows form?
mn33:4.2_0: It’s when a mendicant doesn’t truly understand that all form is the four primary elements, or form derived from the four primary elements.
mn33:4.3_0: That’s how a mendicant doesn’t know form.
mn33:5.1_0: And how is a mendicant not skilled in characteristics?
mn33:5.2_0: It’s when a mendicant doesn’t truly understand that a fool is characterized by their deeds, and an astute person is characterized by their deeds.
mn33:5.3_0: That’s how a mendicant is not skilled in characteristics.
mn33:6.1_0: And how does a mendicant not blow?
mn33:6.2_0: It’s when a mendicant tolerates a sensual, malicious, or cruel thought that has arisen.
mn33:6.2_1: They favor malicious oppose malicious intent.
mn33:6.2_2: or cruel thought that has arisen.
mn33:6.2_3: They tolerate any bad, unskillful qualities that have arisen. They don’t give them up, get rid of them, eliminate them, and obliterate them.
mn33:6.3_0: That’s how a mendicant isn’t runs out of a roof.
mn33:7.10_0: That’s how a mendicant doesn’t conceal it.
mn33:7.1_0: And how does a mendicant not conceal it?
mn33:7.2_0: When a mendicant sees a sight with their eyes, they get caught up in the features and details.
mn33:7.3_0: Since the faculty of sight is left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of desire and aversion become overwhelming. They don’t practice restraint, they don’t protect the faculty of sight, and they don’t achieve its restraint.
mn33:7.4_0: When I heard a sound with my ears ...
mn33:7.5_0: When I smelled an odor with my nose ...
mn33:7.6_0: tastes a flavor with the tongue ...
mn33:7.7_0: feels a touch with the body ...
mn33:7.8_0: know a thought with their mind, they get caught up in the features and details.
mn33:7.9_0: Since the faculty of the mind is left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of desire and aversion become overwhelming. They don’t practice restraint, they don’t protect the faculty of the mind, and they don’t achieve its restraint.
mn33:8.1_0: And how does a mendicant not do this?
mn33:8.2_0: It’s when a mendicant doesn’t teach others the Dhamma in detail as they learned and memorized it.
mn33:8.3_0: That’s how a mendicant doesn’t speaks fught.
mn33:9.1_0: And how does a mendicant not know?
mn33:9.2_0: It’s when a mendicant doesn’t from time to time go up to those mendicants who are very learned—knowledgeable in the scriptures, who have memorized the teachings, the texts on monastic training, and the outlines—and ask them questions:
mn33:9.5_0: Those venerables don’t clarify what is unclear, reveal what is obscure, and dispel doubt regarding the many doubtful matters.
mn33:9.6_0: That’s how a mendicant doesn’t know about.
